channel.title: [c4d] rpg
channel.description:
*Using gay IE which means i have no spellcheck, escuse my grammar, lol.
New thing im working on, im not able to retrieve my living room file atm so i installed c4d and started something else. Im going to keep building up on detail and the model, not so much focus on textures yet. This will all eventually end up as a compositing image of it leaning up against my wall.
Pictures are in order from worst to best.
http://img508.imageshack.us/img508/7901/rpg1so1.png[/img] http://img338.imageshack.us/img338/4951/rpg2sp8.png[/img] http://img512.imageshack.us/img512/1048/rpg3af6.png[/img] http://img395.imageshack.us/img395/9778/rpg4tj4.jpg[/img] http://img367.imageshack.us/img367/263/rpg5tl1.png[/img] http://img528.imageshack.us/img528/8712/rpg6gu9.png[/img] [IMG]http://img504.imageshack.us/img504/418/rpgbackgroundvj5.jpg[/img] [img]http://img353.imageshack.us/img353/7480/rpgru5.jpg[/img]

item.title: [c4d] rpg
item.dc:creator: @the_bank the bank
item.description:
@the_bank wrote:

Very nice, but I think the wood is a bit too glossy. In real life, that thing would be made with harsher wood, not laminated hard wood.

Or, you could cut down on the texture of the wood, and keep the glossy feel.

Just my thoughts.

Read full topic

item.title: [c4d] rpg
item.dc:creator: @SomethingToHide STH
item.description:
@SomethingToHide wrote:

Much better.
Two concerns.
More subd’s on the missile tip, I can see the polys.
Harsher lighting. Use an infinite light or something. And make sure all the edges are exactly touching the ground or maybe through it. It looks like it’s floating.

Read full topic

item.title: [c4d] rpg
item.dc:creator: @SomethingToHide STH
item.description:
@SomethingToHide wrote:

It’s pretty much the materials and lighting. The lighting makes it look really small. And the materials make it seem light.
The lighting makes it look like it’s almost floating. You need to give it like harsh sun lighting so it appears correct size. And make the tiles a lot smaller. IRL that thing would cross many more tiles. That makes it look small.

And the shader on the metal and wood make it seem plastic cause it has no specular or reflections.
It needs a little bit. Not perfect specular or reflections, but diffused.

Read full topic

item.title: [c4d] rpg
item.dc:creator: @SomethingToHide STH
item.description:
@SomethingToHide wrote:

Yes there’s plenty of stuff.

I on the other hand just pretty much learned myself.

Look for UVUnwrapper. It’s free and great. Or you could pirate the pro edition, but the free one does it for me.

Or you could do it all in C4D. Most of the time it’s easier that way. You could get some bodypaint tutorials on that.

Pretty much just Windows/Layout/Bodypaint UV Edit.

Pull out the UVPolygon Selection tool and select polygons, and in the UVManager you can set what type of mapping to apply to it. Then you can move and scale them around to all fit. Then what I do is:

  1. Select all the polygons
  2. If you haven’t, create a material and apply it, and under Color for the texture pick Create New Texture and make it pretty big.
  3. Do a Layer/Outline Polygons
  4. Save that texture

In photoshop you can open that and then you can see the UV Layout and you can paint on that.

Read full topic

item.title: [c4d] rpg
item.dc:creator: @archerer98 Archer
item.description:
@archerer98 wrote:

Download this tutorial on UV mapping, helped me out a lot.

You need to register to see it.

item.title: [c4d] rpg
item.dc:creator: @SomethingToHide STH
item.description:
@SomethingToHide wrote:

You could unwrap the UVs of the object and paint on a texture map.
And while doing that paint things like grime, and scratches on the metal.

Read full topic
